subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Schwa/wedge merger in QS
msgSnippet: Whilst I agree with you that they can be treated as two separate sounds, it does make life very much simpler having the one character for both and I for one am
messageBody:
Whilst I agree with you that they can be treated as two separate sounds, it does make life very much simpler having the one character for both and I for one am never in doubt as to the meaning or pronounciation of the word.  So I would be in favour of retaining the status quo.

Moira

Moira O'Brien LIPF
Moira O'Brien Photography

Tel +353 (0)766-153852
Tel: +44 (0)845-527 9190
Mobile +353 (0)876-214532  
Fax: +44 (0)8701-337953

www.moiraobrien.com
www.corkphotographer.net
www.photographers-united.com

Personal Website www.moirajane.net


2009/5/22 Charles Smith <Roasted_Beanie@...>


I've been wondering about this for a while, and I want everyone's opinion.  What do you think of the fact that schwa /@/ and wedge /V/ share a letter in QS?  Do you agree or disagree with this merger?  Shavian had separate letters for these sounds, which is the way I think it should be. (Also, as a consequence of this merger in QS, the sounds 3` and @` [as well as @r, as in "array"] share the same sequence.)  Has anyone thought to propose an extra letter to make the distinction?  Perhaps one could separate the two versions of #36 to make the distinction.

This isn't to say, however, that I don't like QS, because I do; I've been using it since the early 2000s (on and off admittedly).  If QS were ever to be considered to replace the Latin alphabet, I'd be wholeheartedly in favor of it.  This is just one of the few issues I have with QS.

would be in favour of retaining the status quo.
